item.title: Interview: Once Upon A Puppet Dev Discusses Gameplay, Character Dynamics, and More
item.description:
Developer Flatter Than Earth and publisher Daedalic Entertainment are combining 2.5D platforming and the theater with Once Upon A Puppet , a new game set to launch across all major platforms on April 23. Taking place in a magical kingdom built to resemble a marionette stage show, Once Upon A Puppet puts players in the starring role of two unlikely protagonists. Nieve is a disgraced Stagehand who finds herself bound to a young Puppet by the name of Drev, and the pair must journey to discover the mystery of their predicament and save the world from a consuming darkness.

Game Rant recently spoke to one of the developers of Once Upon A Puppet to learn more about how Flatter Than Earth first came up with the idea for a side-scroller that lets players control both a puppet and the hand literally pulling its strings. They also shared insight into how this symbiotic connection is reflected in Once Upon A Puppet ’s gameplay, how the theater influenced the game’s setting and characters, and the way that in-game collectibles are tied to Once Upon A Puppet ’s lore. This interview has been edited for clarity.

Once Upon A Puppet’s Theatrical Origins Explained

Q. Where did the idea for a puppet and theater-themed platformer come from?

A. The inspiration for Once Upon a Puppet came from a moment of realization. I was already exploring the idea of a game where a character marionettes a puppet, but I wasn’t sure what kind of world they belonged in. Then, I saw a photo of a theater stage. At first, I just scrolled past it, but something made me go back. That image stuck with me.

Suddenly, it clicked - puppets and theater are a perfect match. That’s their natural stage, both literally and metaphorically. From that moment on, everything made sense. I dove deep into researching both theater and puppetry, understanding how they work, their visual language, and how we could translate them into a game. Once that connection was made, there was no going back.

Q. Can you talk a little bit about Once Upon a Puppet’s development journey? What did “day one” look like, and what have the past few months looked like?

A. Once Upon a Puppet started as a small idea, just a rough concept of a game with a puppet controlled by another character. The early days were all about discovery, testing different mechanics, and understanding how puppetry could work in gameplay. A big focus was on movement - how do you make a puppet feel like a puppet, rather than just another platforming character?

As development progressed, we went through a lot of iterations. At first, not everyone on the team fully saw the vision. I spent a lot of time showing them references from theater productions, explaining why this direction was powerful. Once we aligned, the game really came to life.

The past year was about refinement, fine-tuning the controls, polishing the visuals, and making sure the storytelling was as strong as it could be. A lot of love has gone into making the world feel rich, immersive, and deeply theatrical.

Q. What were some of the biggest challenges you faced when translating these puppet/theater themes into story or gameplay?

A. One of the biggest challenges was movement. A puppet doesn’t move like a regular character in a platformer. We didn’t want Drev to just feel like another Mario or Hollow Knight - his movement had to reflect real puppetry. We studied how marionettes move, how the tension in strings affects motion, and how we could make that part of the gameplay.

Another challenge was selling the idea of a theatrical world. We wanted it to feel like a grand stage production, with lighting, set changes, and dramatic storytelling. That meant designing a world that flowed like a Broadway show rather than a confined stage and making sure our 2.5D cutscenes captured that theatrical magic.

Q. What would you say the overall theme of Once Upon A Puppet is?

A. Besides the theme of theater and puppetry, at its core , Once Upon a Puppet is a story about fate, redemption, and self-discovery, which is interwoven very deeply into the story of the King and his son, the Prince. Nieve is a visitor to this arc, yet Drev is part of it.

Speaking of them, Drev and Nieve are literally bound together and must learn to work as one. Their journey is deeply personal, yet intertwined with the larger world of the theater and the fate of the Prince.

Q. Can you talk a little bit about how the game takes advantage of the relationship between hand and puppet? Was gameplay natural in this regard, or did it take a lot of iteration to get right?

It definitely took a lot of iteration! The core idea - one character controlling another like a puppet, felt unique from the start, but making it feel good took time. We had to balance the feeling of control with the unpredictability of a puppet’s movement.

For example, Nieve doesn’t just control Drev directly, there’s a dynamic between them. Drev has his own personality, his own ambitions, and sometimes his movements reflect that. We wanted to make sure players felt like they were truly puppeteering BOTH characters, not just pressing a button to move.

Q. Similarly, can you talk a little bit about fitting puppet gameplay into platformer mechanics, like Drev being able to catapult himself?

A. This was another area where we had to rethink traditional platforming. A puppet doesn’t have the same kind of direct control over its movement, so we had to be creative.

Drev’s ability to catapult himself comes from the idea of manipulating puppet strings. Instead of just pressing jump, the player has to work with the physics of puppetry, pulling back, releasing, and using momentum to their advantage. It creates a different kind of challenge, one that feels more in line with the puppeteering-like theme.

Q. What would you say the overall puzzle ethos is in Once Upon a Puppet?

A. The puzzles in Once Upon a Puppet are built around theatrical storytelling and stage mechanics. Players don’t just solve puzzles in isolation, they’re actively setting up a stage, arranging props, and performing actions that feel like part of a play.

The key idea is transformation: how do you change the stage to advance? That could mean moving backdrops, adjusting lighting, or even stepping into different roles through costumes. The puzzles are meant to feel like they’re part of a grand performance, where every action contributes to the unfolding story.

Also, beware hardcore puzzle players. Once Upon A Puppet is more of a casual puzzler. At FTE, we believe that puzzle platformers are fragile; you get stuck once, and you turn off the game. I did not want that for OUaP , I want the player to keep playing and not get stuck on one puzzle. The whole experience, from A to Z, is what we tried to help the player with.

Q. Promotional materials mention a colorful cast of supporting characters. How did you approach designing these characters?

A. A big inspiration was actual stage productions, how actors take on exaggerated personas, and how costumes and set design tell a story. We wanted every character to feel like they belonged in this world, from their design to their dialogue.

Each character has a theatrical flair. Some are dramatic, some are comedic, but all of them contribute to the feeling that you’re in a living, breathing theater production. And just like in a real play, every character plays a role in the larger story.

Overall, we put a lot of effort into our characters and their details. We really wanted to create a standout case.

Q. The Steam demo includes some collectible glass window shards to collect. What do the collectibles add to Once Upon a Puppet’s gameplay?

A. Collectibles in Once Upon a Puppet serve a deeper purpose than just completionism. The Stained Glass pieces, for example, are tied to the game’s story, and each one reveals part of a larger mystery. Collecting them isn’t just about unlocking rewards; it’s about piecing together the hidden history of our theater world.

They also help in exploring the world, allow the player to be perceptive, look into the theater and notice the stained glass shards.

Beyond that, we have ideas that we would love to implement for the sequel. So keep playing and recommending OUaP to your friends. The future of the sequel depends on it.

Q. What are Flatter Than Earth’s plans come Once Upon A Puppet launches in April? Can you share any ideas for your next project?

A. Right now, we’re fully focused on making sure Once Upon a Puppet launches in the best possible state. We want players to experience the full theatrical magic we’ve worked so hard to create.

As for what’s next, we always have ideas brewing. Our studio is built on the idea of crafting unique, imaginative worlds, so you can expect something just as creative as Once Upon a Puppet . But for now, we’re letting this game take center stage.

Q. Is there anything else you would like to add?

A. I just want to say thank you to everyone who has supported Once Upon a Puppet . This game has been a labor of love, and we can’t wait for players to experience it. Whether you’re a fan of platformers, theater, or just great storytelling, we hope you’ll find something special in this world we’ve created. And remember, every stage tells a story. It’s up to you to bring it to life.

Also - if you’re interested in more indie titles like this one, there’s a wealth of games out there in the retro space that are also doing some really cool stuff - like 8-Bit Adventures 2 , Chained Echoe s, and Quartet !

[END]

item.title: Nintendo Switch Online Adds 3 Classic Sega Genesis Games
item.description:
Summary

  • Nintendo Switch Online adds Sega Genesis games, including Streets of Rage, for Expansion Pack subscribers.
  • Launch of Nintendo Switch 2 on June 5 will bring GameCube titles to Switch Online + Expansion Pack.

Nintendo Switch Online has added three classic Sega Genesis games — Streets of Rage, Super Thunder Blade, and ESWAT: City Under Siege — to the library of titles available with the Expansion Pack. Fans of retro video games can get access to NES, SNES, and Game Boy favorites with a regular Switch Online subscription, and the Expansion Pack adds many iconic N64, Game Boy Advance, and Sega Genesis games to the selection.

Once the Nintendo Switch 2 launches on June 5, Switch Online + Expansion Pack subscribers will be able to enjoy Game Cube titles as well. The announcement that the beloved console would be coming to the service was one of the highlights of the April 2 Nintendo Direct Showcase, and the first games on offer will be F-Zero GX, The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, and Soulcalibur 2.

In the meantime, gamers will be enjoying regular additions to the catalog and other perks like free upgrades via their Switch Online subscription. On April 10, Streets of Rage, Super Thunder Blade, and ESWAT: City Under Siege became available for Expansion Pack subscribers to check out. These classic Sega Genesis titles offer something for fans of side scrollers, flight sims, and beat ‘em ups.

Games Added to Switch Online + Expansion Pack in April

  • ESWAT: City Under Siege
  • Streets of Rage
  • Super Thunder Blade

Of the three new games, Streets of Rage might be the most recognizable, as its 1991 release marked the beginning of a long-lived and successful franchise that comprises four games, numerous fan projects, comics, and short stories. As recently as 2022, there was even a Streets of Rage feature film and television series in the works by Lionsgate, though there haven’t been any updates on that project in a while. This Switch Online addition is a side-scrolling beat ‘em up that pits former police officers against a crime syndicate that has set up base in the fictional city of Wood Oak.

Another side scroller, this time a platformer, ESWAT: City Under Siege was released in 1990. A port of a popular arcade game of the time, with some new levels and weapons tossed into the mix, ESWAT also puts players in the boots of a police officer on a mission to clean up the streets. But despite the similarities in presentation and setting, this Switch Online newcomer offers a completely different experience to Streets of Rage.

The combat flight simulator Super Thunder Blade also pits players against relentless bad guys, but shakes things up a bit by giving them a helicopter to use as a weapon instead. Released in 1988, the popular game has been ported a few times, to PS2 and PSP in 2007 and Xbox 360 and PS3 in 2009, and fans are excited to see it join the many games available with a Switch Online + Expansion Pack subscription.

item.title: Marvel Rivals Comic Teases Several Potential New Skins
item.description:
Summary

  • Marvel Rivals Season 2 introduces the new Vanguard Emma Frost to the popular hero shooter.
  • Gamers can earn a free Scarlet Witch skin by playing nine matches in the new season of Marvel Rivals.
  • Marvel Rivals Infinity Comic teases several potential new skins for the game's iconic heroes.

NetEase Games has teased several potential Marvel Rivals skins in the seventh issue of its crossover comic book, Marvel Rivals Infinity Comic . Marvel Rivals has officially launched Season 2: Hellfire Gala, which introduced Emma Frost to the popular hero shooter as its newest Vanguard, with Ultron expected to arrive in a large mid-season update.

Gamers who jump into the new season will have the ability to earn a free skin for the Duelist Scarlet Witch in Marvel Rivals . After playing three matches, players will be able to claim a nameplate featuring the popular hero. Once fans have played nine matches of the new season, they will be rewarded with Scarlet Witch's brand-new Chaos Gown outfit.

In a post on Twitter, Miller Ross pointed out that the most recent issue of Marvel Rivals Infinity Comic gives players a glimpse of several heroes wearing costumes that haven't been seen in the game. Some characters are sporting fancy Hellfire Gala attire, while others appear to be in summer outfits during a beach outing. The comic showcased heroes like Marvel Rivals ' Doctor Strange, Jeff the Land Shark, Magik, Storm, The Thing, Squirrel Girl, and more.

Marvel Rivals Infinity Comic Showcases Several New Costumes

According to Miller Ross, the Hellfire Gala outfit for Magik in Marvel Rivals might be free for players to claim as part of a story event during Season 2, though there has been no official announcement as of writing. Many people have been clamoring to see NetEase Games add the iconic outfit, as it seems to be a fan-favorite within the community.

Those who wish to view the outfits for themselves may want to check out Marvel Unlimited, where they can read all seven issues of the Marvel Rivals Infinity Comic . Players who are subscribed to Marvel Unlimited on April 25 will even receive a free skin for The Thing in Marvel Rivals . Fans don't even have to purchase a subscription, as they can claim a free month of Marvel Unlimited by using the promo code HEREISTHETHING by April 17.

Gamers looking for more free cosmetics may be happy to learn that they can earn the Flora Maiden costume for Mantis in Marvel Rivals , by completing challenges associated with the Cerebro Database event. Players can also claim a free skin for the Duelist Namor as part of the Twitch Drops that launched with Season 2. With a whole new season to experience and even more content on the way, many fans are feeling hopeful about the future of Marvel Rivals .

item.title: Crashlands 2: How to Get Pets
item.description:
There's plenty to explore in Crashlands 2, and players won't have to run around the wilderness alone. You can have companions to help you do stuff while exploring, and getting them is much simpler than you'd think.

Having a pet is as cool as it is fulfilling, and once you start feeling the pressure in fights, they can lend a helping hand if needed. In this Crashlands 2 guide, we'll be covering how to find and raise your first pet as well as some tips on how to get more of them.

How to Get a Pet in Crashlands 2

You can get your first pet fairly early on. After contacting the denizens of Haarlipol, you'll get a quest called Looks Like BS , which will have you exploring Sluggabun Grotto far to the west of the town. You may want to bring some Popcork Docks with you if you want to reach the Grotto easily. Popcork Docks will also help you reach Juice Jems that are hidden on small patches of land surrounded by water.

Once you're at Sluggabun Grotto, explore the area until you find a Sluggabun egg further to the west. This will start a quest called A Good Egg ,

A Good Egg Quest

This is a relatively short quest that will send you to Thunder Fields , which is directly south of the Crash Pod. The steps are fairly easy to follow — speak with NPCs, defeat enemies, speak with NPCs again, and so on.

Here, you'll meet Baani and Clood, two ranchers who are having a bit of a pest problem. Clear out the Ampybaras in their ranch (make sure to check the barns too), and they'll give you advice on how to care for the Sluggabun egg you found.

In the future, you can find more pets by completing quests or by finding them in the world.

How to Raise Pets

If you want to raise a pet in the Crashlands sequel, you'll need to nest eggs in the correct environments . As far as the Sluggabun egg is concerned, you must build and place a nest, and put it in a room with the following conditions:

  • The room must be cramped.
  • The room must be away from workstations.
  • The egg must be near a Poplamp.

For this egg, you can make a small 1x3 room that has enough space for a Poplamp and a Woven Nest. Make sure that it satisfies all conditions needed for it to be considered a room (it must be enclosed with walls and a door).

Once you've placed the egg in a room with the right conditions, it will start incubating. Eventually, it will hatch, and your new pet will emerge.

item.title: CUKTECH 10 100W Wall Charger Unboxing - Game Rant Mailbag
item.description: Today we take a look at the CUKTECH 10 100W Wall Charger. This is a great purhcase for anyone looking for a versitile way to charge your different devices. It features different voltage levels meant for different device requirements. It also has a small and sleek design perfect for the inside of travel packs.
